Description: Uninscribed electrum oyster-shell amulet, probably formed by beating in a mould. The ring, soldered at the top, is worn by the rubbing of a thread or wire. The shell represented is probably Avicula (Meleagrina) margaritacea.
Curator's comments: These shell amulets were called 'wḏʒw', A. Erman and H. Grapow, 'Wörterbuch der aegyptische Sprache im Auftrage der deutschen Akademie’ I (Leipzig, 1926), 401, i.e. 'healthy ones'. See F. Jéquier, ‘Les Frises d’objets des sarcophages du Moyen Empire. Institut français d’archéologie orientale di Caire. Mémoires publiés par les Membres’ vol. 47 (Cairo, 1921),58-60. For 'Avicula (Meleagrina) margaritacea', see H. E. Winlock, ‘The Treasure of Three Egyptian Princesses’ (New York, 1948), 25, n. 33: Petrie's 'Meleagrina margaritifera', see W. M. F. Petrie, ‘Amulets’ (London, 1914), 27, no. 112. Uninscribed Middle Kingdom oyster-shell amulets are fairly common, and were intended to ensure the good health of their wearers. Bibliography: Sotheby and Son, 'Catalogue of Mr Salt's Collection of Egyptian Antiquities, 28th June to 8th July, 1835' (London), lot 647; The British Museum, ‘Synopsis of the Contents of the British Museum’ (London, 1850), 240, case 82; The British Museum, ‘Synopsis of the Contents of the British Museum. Department of Oriental Antiquities: First and Second Egyptian Rooms’ (London, 1879), 72. Published: Andrews, Amulets of Ancient Egypt (1994): fig.43 Published: Andrews, Amulets of Ancient Egypt (1994): fig.43
Bibliographic references: Andrews 1981 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities. Jewellery I (407)
Acquisition notes: Lot 647 at sale. The evidence for provenance given in the Salt Sale Catalogue is not always completely reliable.
